newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian Broadcasting Corp Midday Update.
newsitem.headline: Australian Broadcasting Corp Midday Update.

text.p: WIK MEETING UNDERWAY
In Canberra, State and Territory leaders have gone into a meeting with the Prime Minister about native title still divided about how to resolve problems raised by the High Court's Wik decision.
Mr Howard believes his ten-point plan is the most fair and practical way to resolve the impasse over native title on pastoral leases.
But the plan hasn't won support from all the States, and some Premiers say there is unlikely to be a resolution from today's meeting.
RUNDLE CALLS FOR CONTINUED VIGILANCE ON GUN CONTROL
Tasmania's Premier, Tony Rundle, has called for continued vigilance on gun control.

Today is the first anniversary of the Port Arthur massacre in which 35 people were shot dead by lone gunman, Martin Bryant. Mr Rundle says it would be a tragedy to reverse the decision to tighten gun laws, and says the passing of this anniversary shouldn't see any relaxation in those efforts.
The Premier says the establishment of national fire-arms reforms was a remarkable achievement, and it must be ensured there's no political platform for the reversal of those laws.
MEMORIAL TO BE BEAMED AROUND THE GLOBE
In Tasmania, mourners are gathering at Port Arthur for the first anniversary memorial service for the victims of the tragic massacre.
Thirty-five people died after being shot by Martin Bryant at the historic site a year ago today.
Seating for 300 has been provided in the ruins of the old convict church, with an audio backdrop of the soundtrack from the movie, Schindler's List.
A large media contingent is at the site to record the service which will be beamed around the world.
JAPANESE PM's VISIT
A 19-gun salute will signal Australia's official welcome to Japanese Prime Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, when he arrives at Parliament house in Canberra this afternoon.
Mr Hashimoto arrived in Sydney earlier today and is sight-seeing there before flying to the capital.
Prime Minister, John Howard will welcome the Japanese leader at Parliament House.
Mr Hashimoto will give a key-note speech tonight to a Parliamentary dinner in which he's expected to endorse Australia's future role in the Asia-Pacific.
The Japanese PM will attend trade and defence talks during his two day visit.
HEARING DELAYED AFTER ELEVATOR AND HEALTH PROBLEMS
The committal hearing of two men, charged in connection with the bashing death of a British tourist at Sydney's Bondi Beach last year, has been delayed for about two-hours.
Twenty-eight-year-old Brian Hagland died while walking home with his girlfriend near Bondi Beach last September.
Twenty-three year old Aaron Martin has been charged with murder, while another 23-year-old man, Sean Cushman, has been charged with accessory after the fact of murder.
The start of the hearing at Sydney's Darling Centre Local Court has been delayed until this afternoon, after Mr Martin and his barrister got stuck in a court lift and his mother later collapsed.
COMPETITION FOR GOVERNMENT LEGAL ADVISER
The Federal Government's internal legal adviser, the Attorney General's Legal Practice, is to be opened up to competition from July next year.

Attorney General Daryl Williams says the Legal Practice which is largely based in Canberra, will be restructured as a statutory organisation, known as the Australian Government Solicitor, but remain under his direction.
Under the reforms the organisation will continue to meet the Commonwealth's legal needs, but government departments will have greater freedom to appoint their own lawyers.
Mr Williams says the increased competition will allow the government to make further savings in legal costs.
DEMOCRATS ATTACK EFFORTS TO CIRCUMVENT ANDREWS LAW
The Territory branch of the Australian Democrats has attacked efforts to circumvent the Andrews anti voluntary euthanasia law.
Labor's John Bailey last week introduced a private members bill to the Territory parliament making an offence of euthanasia, with minimal penalties.
The Australian Democrats are collecting a petition for a referendum in all states and Territories on voluntary euthanasia, to highlight public opinion.
Territory spokesman Vick Edwards says Mr Bailey is going the wrong way about it.
AWU THREATENS ACTION IF MASSIVE CUT MEANS JOB LOSSES
The Australian Workers Union says the two-thousand possible job losses forced by the partial closure of BHP's Newcastle steel mill could force national industrial action.
The union's Newcastle secretary, Maurie Rudd, says members are expecting a statement from management on the mill's future tomorrow.
Mr Rudd told ABC radio, BHP's likely to announce the closure, rather than updating of the mill's blast furnaces and coke ovens.
He says he believes BHP is planning to get out of steel in Australia.
